title: How does it feel to be able to see after being blind your whole life (or part of it)? - Quora

response.answer_text: Here is an article that addresses that question that you might be interested in: What People Cured of Blindness See - The New Yorker And another article: Blind Man Sees For First Time As Result Of Accident And this: Can a blind person whose vision is restored understand what she sees? And perhaps you might be interested in this book (The Mind's Eye): The Mind's Eye | Oliver Sacks, M.D. | Author, Neurologist | On The Move, Hallucinations, Musicophilia, Awakenings, The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat You might also be interested in this book: Crashing Through: The Extraordinary True Story of the Man Who Dared to See: Robert Kurson: 9780812973686: Amazon.com: Books Best regards!

I wasn't blind per se but I was physically unable to open my eyes for a while after a stroke. It. Was. TERRIFYING. I could still hear (thank goodness) but all I could see is if it was dark or light.If the doctor/nurse didn't talk to me I had NO clue what was going on. I'm 27 now (I was 19 then) and I'm still afraid of the dark. Being able to see again was AMAZING.

I can only relate what people say to me. First, they feel like they can finally relate the sound and smell of phenomena with a visual image. Second, they are definitely that they can be more mobile. Lastly, they love their loved ones.  BTW, people with total blindness from birth are not likely to see like sighted people. Their cortical cells are not present for even retinal implants to work well.
The late neurologist Oliver Sacks explored this in his text: AN ANTHROPOLOGIST ON MARS in an chapter entiled: “To See And Not See.” The text may give you some insight into your question’s answer.
